beta.title: Beta Distribution
beta.section1.title: 1. Definition and Interpretation
beta.section1.intro: The Beta distribution is a continuous probability distribution defined on the interval $(0,1)$ with two shape parameters $\alpha$ and $\beta$.
beta.section1.intuition: It models random variables that represent proportions or probabilities, such as the success rate in a Bernoulli trial.
beta.section1.scenarios: Common scenarios include Bayesian inference, modeling of proportions, and reliability analysis.
beta.section1.rel1: When $\alpha = \beta = 1$, it reduces to the Uniform$(0,1)$ distribution.
beta.section1.rel2: It is the conjugate prior of the Binomial, Negative Binomial, and Geometric distributions.
beta.section1.rel3: It has transformation relationships with the Gamma and F distributions.
beta.section2.title: 2. Analytical Forms
beta.section2.cdf: CDF: $$F(x;\alpha,\beta) = I_x(\alpha,\beta)$$, where $I_x$ is the regularized incomplete Beta function.
beta.section2.ppf: PPF (inverse CDF): no closed form, computed numerically.
beta.section3.title: 3. Graphs
beta.section4.title: 4. Additional Notes
beta.section4.special: Special cases: $\alpha = \beta = 1 \Rightarrow U(0,1)$$; $$\alpha = 1, \beta > 1$ gives a decreasing distribution; $\alpha > 1, \beta = 1$ gives an increasing distribution.
beta.section4.usage: Widely used as a prior in Bayesian statistics due to conjugacy with the Binomial distribution.
beta.section5.title: 5. Functions in R
beta.section5.desc: Common R calls for the Beta distribution:
beta.section5.code:
## PDF
dbeta(x, shape1 = alpha, shape2 = beta)

## CDF
pbeta(x, shape1 = alpha, shape2 = beta)

## Quantile (PPF)
qbeta(p, shape1 = alpha, shape2 = beta)

## Random generation
rbeta(n, shape1 = alpha, shape2 = beta)
beta.section5.paramNote: Parameters: shape1 = alpha > 0, shape2 = beta > 0; functions are vectorized in x (or p).
